title: sunsilk
author: sunsilk
content: So, I was casually browsing on the web and saw this hilarious story about Ryhan Serhant(agent) offered to buy 2 bedroom apartment in New York for 50,000 Bitcoin ($13,000,000) for his client on 2015. That's around $260 per Bitcoin on that time.Now, that 50,000 Bitcoins is now worth $5B ($100k/btc). Yeah, that's a lot now and if that deal went through there will be for sure some holdings left on that seller but it didn't happen and the seller didn't like the idea and the worth of its valuation at that time because the value and the listing price of the apartment should be around $13,950,000 - $14,000,000 compared to the offer of the buyer which was valued less than approx a $1M. Man, we gotta love all of these Bitcoin purchases in the past and the sellers didn't accept any of these offers. I'm sure that there are other documented purchases that ended up the same.Full story and video: Man turned down a 50,000 Bitcoin house offer in 2015 and it’s worth a shocking amount todayX video link on the image below.

I'm sure that there are other documented purchases that ended up the same.Full story and video: Man turned down a 50,000 Bitcoin house offer in 2015 and it’s worth a shocking amount todayX video link on the image below.Business is not for shallow minded people that are afraid of taking risk, it involves calculated risk, decision making and endurance. Although you cannot blame the seller of the apartment for rejecting the offer of 50,000  bitcoins for the purchase of the apartment because he never new that Bitcoin will appreciate to where it is today. Anyone may likely do the same because selling an apartment that may be likely under insurance for 50, 000 bitcoins when you cannot predict the future of Bitcoin or when there is no assurance covering that 50000 Bitcoin is a whole lot of risk.I'm sure there are many cases like this and if truly the seller of the apartment knew that Bitcoin will appreciate to where it is today I'm sure he would have everage that opportunity and by now he would have been swimming in ocean of wealth.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: It's amusing how fiat and Bitcoin offer similar yet opposite stories. I'm amazed whenever my grandparents tell me stories of the past, of how hectares of land could be bought for a few dollars or even swapped for a pair of scissors or even canned goods. Those are somewhat similar stories with early Bitcoin purchases in that we can see the huge change in a currency's value over time. They're opposite, however, because fiat's value is going south, depreciating, while Bitcoin's is going north, appreciating. I remember Malmi, Sirius on this forum, sharing how he sold more than 10,000BTC in 2011 to buy a studio apartment. Now, that amount is valued more than a billion USD. That could already build a luxurious mansion in the Bahamas. These stories clearly illustrate which currency is better.

comments.author: Majestic-milf
comments.body: If only the owner of the house know what he gave up! In life, everything's about time and patience. The agent at the time was willing to part with such an amount in Bitcoin because he needed the house and probably it was located in an upscale area of the city but today, I doubt that the value of that house would be up to amount the Bitcoin would be worth so if anything, it's the owner of the house that would have gained greatly(that's if he had held it from that period till now though. There are times where it's necessary to take some risks in business as you can't achieve big things if you don't. Really wish I knew about Bitcoin back in it's early days and purchased me some.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: Damn, New York is outrageously expensive...In stories like this you always have to ask how many bitcoins did the person own in first place that they could offer up 50k from that stash this easily. I'd say we might have had a big ass whale with a lot more than just 50k bitcoins.Additionally we can not really blame the seller either because the offer was $1 million below the ask price. In other words if they really wanted to invest in bitcoin they could have sold their property for $14 million fiat and then bought 3846 more bitcoins with that fiat which is an additional $0.38 billion profit ($5.38 billion total).Also lets not forget that 2015 was mostly a bear market year and filled with lots of FUD. To the point when even by the end of the year one of bitcoin core developers, Mike Hearn spread a FUD calling bitcoin "dead"! I wouldn't really blame anybody who didn't want to touch bitcoin back then.P.S. It is interesting to look back at all the FUD some of us have endured all these years and still kept HODLing...

Those are somewhat similar stories with early Bitcoin purchases in that we can see the huge change in a currency's value over time. They're opposite, however, because fiat's value is going south, depreciating, while Bitcoin's is going north, appreciating. I remember Malmi, Sirius on this forum, sharing how he sold more than 10,000BTC in 2011 to buy a studio apartment. Now, that amount is valued more than a billion USD. That could already build a luxurious mansion in the Bahamas. These stories clearly illustrate which currency is better. Difference between regular money and Bitcoin is really interesting. Your grandparents stories about buying land for little bit of money or trading things for it are great examples of how value of regular money can go down over time. On the other hand Bitcoin value has gone up a lot as shown by Malmi story of selling 10,000 Bitcoins in 2011. Fact that those Bitcoins would be worth over billion dollars today is amazing. These stories show that Bitcoin has potential to be good way to store value and that its value can go up over time making it attractive alternative to traditional currencies.

comments.author: Joel_Jantsen
comments.body: The fact that he could buy something with a digital currency would have been more fascinating to him than the price of Bitcoin. This isn't just about Bitcoin but any tradable commodity like Gold, Silver, and even more primitive the land prices. Unlike gold & silver bitcoin is not a physical commodity which makes it perfect to appear in the headlines. I'm sure many of us would have stories like this if you've been on the forum since the beginning. I've won a lot of luck-based games on the forum or other simple tasks where getting paid 1 BTC plus wasn't a big deal.

comments.author: AVE5
comments.body: Maybe we don't just have to blame the seller because the value of the offer then wasn't lesser than the worth of the apartment after being evaluated.So the trade scene should be expected that the seller would have to make some feasible interest of profits at the selling point.Perhaps that was strickly a business and looking deep to it, the seller would had actually sold the apartment at lost price but would only recover and achieve his profits if he'd to hold for like approximately 9 years as at the 2015 the deal was negotiated and the year 2024 which bitcoin gained the $100,000 values.So I don't think if then and now of nothing evaluation values was necessary to be compared because it'd ideally be that you want to force the seller into another nature of investment if he'd have to accept the offer and also have to wait up til the day bitcoin surged $100,000.We should also have to evaluate the current cost price of the apartment over the 9 years, then we'd also find increase in value of the apartment because real estate assets too is such a bumping that increase in values in time as the nature of economy keep going tough.I literally find the seller not to be bitcoin enthusiasts and doesn't future believe on bitcoin otherwise, he'd had accepted the offer because nomatter how increase in value that apartment could be now, it definitely can't be compared to the value of what the value offered on bitcoin then is compared to now.He really missed out though but otherwise, he didn't lost too as he's more focused on real life assets.

comments.author: Die_empty
comments.body: Quote from: Majestic-milf on January 17, 2025, 03:47:50 AM If only the owner of the house know what he gave up! In life, everything's about time and patience. Really wish I knew about Bitcoin back in it's early days and purchased me some.  The buyer's offer was one million dollars less, so it was not a good deal for the seller. No real estate agent will want to sell his property at a loss, therefore I don't blame him for rejecting the offer. In 2015 Bitcoin was not a popular currency or asset. It will take a core believer of Bitcoin who knows that the price will appreciate to accept such an offer. We keep on hearing these stories and we are reminded that the Bitcoin will have now shouldn't be wasted because of small profits. Bitcoin can skyrocket to an unimaginable amount, as we sell, let's also have good plans to replenish our wallets.

First group of people are the Pizza guy group. Those who bought items for a lot of bitcoins because they felt at that then that is was a useless piece of idea/ token that will not amount to anything.The second set of people are those who refused to accept  a lot of bitcoins which was offered to them for payment of goods and services  8 - 10 years ago because they thought it was a useless piece of idea/ token that will not amount to anything.

comments.author: NotATether
comments.body: I thought this was going to be about the pizza transaction, and I said to myself "not again". Good to see a change for once. Maybe as time goes by, people will unearth more of these exotic kinds of transactions from when Bitcoin was still in the early age.Anyway, I don't think it mattered whether or not it went through, more than the fact that a two-bedroom NYC apartment sells for 14 million dollars? WTF? Was he trying to rent out floors on a skyscraper or something?

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Few people would have accepted Bitcoin in that amount 10 years ago, especially considering that the Mt.Gox case was still fresh and the price had dropped from $1100 to only about $200. I remember that time well because that's when I bought my first BTC and the people I talked to about told me it was a scam and to sell them as soon as possible.I don't blame anyone who turned down the offer then, because there are those who would still turn it down today. According to some statistics, only about 5% of people are in some way involved in cryptocurrencies, and of that number even less directly in BTC.

comments.author: kryptqnick
comments.body: I haven't heard of this story before, but I'm sure there've been plenty of regretful decisions. The thing is, though, even if the seller had agreed back then, he probably would have sold BTC well before it reached its current price. $100k per BTC was not unimaginable in 2015, but it was more of a crazy fantasy than anything real. So even Bitcoin started growing and reached around $1k, it already seemed like a great price. And I remember how surprised I was when Bitcoin grew past $15k in 2017, it seemed impossibly high.So instead of regret, it's good to learn from mistakes of the past and make different decisions in the future.

comments.author: Alone055
comments.body: $14m in 2015? Man, that was expensive as hell. The average rent in NYC at present is around $4,000 or something, and based on that, you pay approximately $48,000 a year, or round it up to $50,000. This means you can rent an apartment, maybe bigger than a 2-bedroom one, for 20 years and pay nothing more than $1m. For someone who isn't a celebrity or a billionaire, renting is probably a better option based on how much money you can save with it instead of buying a house unless you are getting one for much less than that or unless you are doing it as an investment and hope to sell it for a profit.Things could have been different if the seller had accepted the offer and had some of those Bitcoins left somewhere in a wallet that he could access today, but just like any of us, he didn't know Bitcoin would be worth $100k one day. I used to have Bitcoin in the initial days and I used to sell them for fiat because I needed money to spend on things, and even I could have a lot of money if I had saved all of that for today.
